questiontext.text:
Evaluate the sum of the infinite series :
$$\small \sum _{n=0}^{\infty }\:[-4(\frac{1}{4})^n+4(\frac{1}{7})^n]$$

[Calculate upto 2 significant figures]

Answer :
{1:NUMERICAL:=-0.66667:0.05#Good job!!~*#Incorrect, try again}

generalfeedback.text:
This contains two geometric series where the following is given :
First term : a1 = a2 = a = 1 [At n=0 , the first term for both the series will be to the power 0 which equals 1]
Common ratios : r1 = $$\small \frac{1}{4}$$ ,r2 = $$\small \frac{1}{7}$$
Number of terms(n) = $$\small \infty$$

The Sum of a Geometric series is given by :
$$\small \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r}$$ where a is the first term , r is the common difference and n is the number of terms

As n = $$\small \infty$$, Sum = $$\small \frac{a}{1 - r}$$
Sum1 = $$\small \frac{a}{1 - r_{1}}$$ ; Sum2 = $$\small \frac{a}{1 - r_{2}}$$
Sum1 = 1.3333  Sum2 = 1.1667

Total Sum = (-4) * Sum1 + (4) * Sum2
Total Sum = -0.66667

First term : a1 = a2 = a = 1 [At n=0 , the first term for both the series will be to the power 0 which equals 1]
Common ratios : r1 = $$\small \frac{1}{2}$$ ,r2 = $$\small \frac{1}{8}$$
Number of terms(n) = $$\small \infty$$

The Sum of a Geometric series is given by :
$$\small \frac{a(1 - r^{n})}{1 - r}$$ where a is the first term , r is the common difference and n is the number of terms

As n = $$\small \infty$$, Sum = $$\small \frac{a}{1 - r}$$
Sum1 = $$\small \frac{a}{1 - r_{1}}$$ ; Sum2 = $$\small \frac{a}{1 - r_{2}}$$
Sum1 = 2  Sum2 = 1.1429

Total Sum = (2) * Sum1 + (3) * Sum2
Total Sum = 7.4286
